pros: Competitive pay, advocating management, okay benefits, always has resources
cons: Heavy workload, PCTs won’t draw blood

review_title: Best Health Care system to work for in Savannah.
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Savannah, GA
pros: Overall, the Health Care System stives to support and communicate with its employee's. We have a coworker council, nursing council, and mission and values council to encourage communication and feedback. Both hospitals strive to support the mission and values which are courtesy, quality, integrity, compassion, accountability and teamwork. And teamwork is strong in most areas.
cons: In some areas, the management doesn't take advantage of the councils that are in place and the clinical staff especially nurses feel unsupported. Especially the night shift.

pros: Health insurance benefits, PTO. That's it.
cons: Staff Nurses do not get raises.

job_title: Oncology Retail Coordinator  in Savannah, GA
pros: Ok Benefits. and one free birthday lunch a year. Doctors get free lunch daily.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Savannah, GA

cons: Heard some jobs offering higher base pay

pros: We work for a truly amazing organization. Many of us never really found our place until now. I say this especially because I am surrounded by co-workers who are committed to selflessly serving other before themselves. I love my job.
cons: We are super busy and that can be stressful at times. Needs are great.

pros: Great company to work for
cons: You will need to decide for yourself

pros: Easy to pick up extra shifts

pros: Working with a great group of professionals.
cons: Can't think of any at the moment.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Savannah, GA
pros: The hospital itself isn't bad-- St. Joes is definitely more high-tech than Candler, it's not dirty, staff is competent.
cons: If you aren't religious, I wouldn't recommend working here. Religion is completely shoved down your throat, and some nurses admittingly believe more in the power of prayer than modern medicine. For example, I was told that taking anti-depressants is a waste of time and that people's problems could simply be solved by "speaking to God." Also, I was paid 12 dollars an hour as a PCT and worked like a dog, being responsible for 40 patients by myself, especially on med surge floors where they can't keep staff to save their lives.

pros: Great teamwork and valued for what you do.
cons: The pay is a huge con. Benefits also are lacking.

pros: Great benefits, working relationships, longevity, opportunity for growth
cons: Dated systems, lack of support, high turnover

pros: Best health system in the region for patients and employees. They are very caring, generous, fair and understanding. Love working here!
cons: I really can't think of any because it is a great place to work!

pros: loved working here even if i had to work extra
cons: long hours a lot of the time but worth it

job_title: Help Desk Technician in Savannah, GA
pros: Childcare, full benefits, own space, small team, company involvement
cons: Micro management, late nights, set but not so set schedule

job_title: PCT Patient Care Tech in Savannah, GA

cons: Workload is out of hand

job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Savannah, GA
pros: Because many people don't stay, it's easy to obtain experience in higher positions and more complex specialties.
cons: They have essentially monopolized the area. As such, they keep wages as low as possible, while scrutinizing the staff. You are tracked everywhere you go via your badge. Even your handwashing habits are tracked. They will get rid of you in a heartbeat, even nurses

pros: Pretty good insurance benefits in network.
cons: Work atmosphere has changed over time.

pros: Steady work. Mostly a team environment. I would recommend this hospital for other departments within it.
cons: It would be a business advantage to hire qualified, experienced personnel. Not paid for your experience or skill level. Professionalism needs to be a priority. Could never get a day off for much needed MRI because supervisor couldn't get coverage for my location.

pros: A quality nonprofit healthcare system with a Christian-focused culture. The organization hosts many events for the benefit of patients and the well-being of the staff. Discount off employee wellness and great benefits package.
cons: Some of the workers are too involved in the personal lives of their fellow colleagues to the point where it interferes with individual performance. The analytics software used to evaluate business performance is a bit dated (the organization uses the ARIA electronic medical record system instead of a more modern EMR such as Epic).

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Savannah, GA
pros: great place to get experience, great people
cons: they could have a higher pay

job_title: RN Float Pool in Savannah, GA
pros: Different areas and never bored
cons: Sometimes get called off and have to search for a shift

job_title: Staff Nurse (RN), Emergency Room in Savannah, GA
pros: Coworkers have your back, great place for newer nurses to learn and move up, but as an experienced nurse not much room for growth. Doctors work pretty well with nurses, but can be cliquey.
cons: Managers blame staff for all short comings on their behalf, they rarely care about employees, only numbers. They legit were more worried about a gps monitoring hand washing percentage that rarely worked right over nurses working sick and burned out. Worked with fevers, Covid, you name it, you call out and you aren’t besties with the manager, then you get wrote up. However many nurses in the ER were constantly late, had multiple call outs and never had a word said. 1 nurse left in the middle of the shift for over 2 hours (patient abandonment) and didn’t even get a slap on the wrist. Patient to nurse ratio was unreal during peak Covid and flu seasons…. If you were in triage you could be sitting alone with over 60 plus in the lobby for hours on end getting yelled at with no help from charge nurses or doctors. Pay is awful, mere pennies for what they expect of you. And Dear CEO Hinchey…. So glad you got to go to Hawaii while the rest of us were stuck inside during hurricane season!! Those extra funds were well spent!! What a crook!

job_title: Diagnostic Radiologic Technologist in Savannah, GA
pros: Great hours available for work
cons: Low pay for the area.

pros: The health system's mission and values really speak to those that have a passion and calling to the health care industry. The work environment is positive in nature. Leadership has made very good decisions through the years to make SJC a top performing health system, and premiere place to work.
cons: Depending on your unit, promotion opportunities may be more limited.

job_title: Registered Nurse (Per Diem) in Savannah, GA

review_title: Better than the other hospital in the area, but not great
pros: SJCHS is not a for-profit hospital system like HCA is. The system does lots of indigent care. It's also a small system, so staff members all know each other and are friendly.
cons:
This hospital overworks nurses and doesn't care if units are short-staffed every single shift. The incentive offered to pick up shifts is laughable. 

The nurse-to-patient ratio promised to you is something that is seen maybe once a month at most, so basically it's a lie. Because of this short-staffing, dangerous mistakes are often made, and patients suffer. Also, the system uses MEDITECH, the absolute worst EHR system in the world.

pros:

- A lot of emphasis on the "good ol' boy" philosophy instead of ones abilities.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Savannah, GA
pros: Work like balance was good

pros: It is a magnet hospital, meaning you will get the best care in the region.  People all over the hospital have passion, that burning in your belly to give it all to make you better. They walk the talk when it come to values.  I was very proud to be part of that.  Very team-oriented.  Once you have that St. Joseph's/Candler badge hanging from you left pocket, you are gold.  Every team member treats you with respect.  Always reminded me of "all for one, one for all."
cons: Although this hospital system has a great mission ("Rooted in God's love, we treat illness and promote wellness for all people."), vision ("to set the standards of excellence in the delivery of health care throughout the regions we serve."), and values (compassion, quality, integrity, courtesy, accountability, and team work), it falls short on diversity.  From the board of trustees (only one African American physician, four females (three are nuns, and since it is a faith-based institution it is expected) out of 19 positions leaves 74% white male) to senior leadership (all vp's are white males).  Mid-level leadership (director level), you will also find a white canvas, with the exception of facilites management.  Get where I'm going?

review_title: Does NOT reward long term employment or loyal employees
pros: Fellow employees are a joy to work with, campus is very nicely landscaped, great mission services department that serves needy, rooted in Christian values
cons: Recently reevaluated and removed approximately 2 days of PTO per year for any employee over 10 years of service. Over 1 year ago gave the entire organization a 2%  raise to all employees. There is no incentive or pay associated with an employees actual work performance. Broken promises. Terrible parking availability.

pros:
Great group of coworkers
Good weekend differentials
cons:
Unsafe.  You put your license in jeopardy most days.  Too many patients per nurse.  High acuity patients, most days no pct or na.  Lucky to have a charge nurse at all.  Running constantly to find equipment, etc.  Weekends no juice, snacks and many times no available linen.  Buildings are old, furniture in disrepair, heating and air needs 
replacement.  Many patient complaints of being "hot" so wasted time spent locating fans or calling maintenance.  I dread going to work these days.  Real shame cause I enjoy what I do.

pros:
Competent , friendly staff
Multidisciplinary approach to healthcare 
location
Magnet hospital ( supposed to benefit staff as well :)
Shared  revenue contribution to employees 401k yearly
cons:
Matrix change for staff nurses  'to reflect nationwide trend in increased  patient  work load' reflects poor management  as it is only the staff nurses workload that has been increased not  management's,  their immediate support staff, or nursing assistants even.
Designated resource coordinators and managers  more interested in bed turnover as opposed to staffs breaks, meal times, or work load stress.  'are you a robot', yes.
Assignments based upon 'numbers' not acuity or fairness 
Nursing care assistants  (not all)  that take their minimum  wage  seriously with minimum return
Unused pto benefit slashed to half (tho admittedly not an employee entitlement but 'gifted' thru managment)

pros: Great community based resources.  Co-workers are professionally driven.  It's an added bonus that the organization is religiously affiliated.
cons: Although this organization strives for nationally recognized certifications and accolades, and has somehow managed to acquire some prominent awards and designations, there is a general sense of unbelief from those in the know, at least in the clinical setting.  For years and years within this organization there has been a serious lack of resources, in regards to "boots on the ground".  Organizationally, the clinical staff, in particular, are begging and screaming for additional resources (more staff and lower nurse-patient ratios)-- but this continues to fall on deaf ears.  It is but one example of management and administration holding the "voice" of it's employees in the lowest regard.  There is considerable staff turnover, across all departments, and there is no effort given in retaining current employees.  Additionally, there is no investigation done as to why an individual is leaving-- no exit interviews.  If there was, you would hear a huge percentage cite the lack of being heard and the lack of additional help, as the primary reasons for departure.  The sense of "team" is given very little attention within this organization and this stems from a lack of inclusion and actual 'leading' by management.  Yearly pay increases are laughable, if not insulting.  The pay is below standard and employees are not incentivized properly, if at all.

pros: Great co-workers who make job bearable. 401 K employee match up to 4%.
cons: Always understaffed.  Always looking for equipment and supplies.  Medication carts are old and often do not work or so slow it might take up t0 15 min. to get it working properly if at all.  Sometimes no adequate or uninterrupted break.  Managers micromanage and create a very punitive work environment.

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Savannah, GA
pros: Plenty of hours, great coworkers, great department, benefits, experience for nursing
cons: Low pay, a lot of dirty work for lazy nurses, a lot of being a medically licensed janitor at times, impatient patients that take anger out on you since you're the first person they have contact with in the ED

pros:
Freedom to schedule my patients weekly according to their need and my need. 
Easy to use system for documentation

cons:
No weekly team meetings to communicate with other disciplines makes it harsa to communicate regularly with them
Nursing is run by hospital and Pt/OT through contract company thus not always on same page.
